poem:
"Misplaced Substitutions"

Mushroom in lieu of tampon, odd trade indeed,
Frozen pizza usurping tinned peaches, an absurd creed. 
Cream cracker with Christmas cheer, misplaced words in deed,
In the automated aisles, where computer whims lead.
A third of buyers, their orders misread,
Asda's strange deals, a customer's dyslexic dread.
Retelling not the tale of bounty,
But of peculiar poverty instead.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Mushrooms swapped for tampons among bizarre UK supermarket substitutions Mushrooms in place of tampons, a frozen pizza substituted for tinned peaches, and cream crackers instead of Christmas crackers. These are among the “bizarre” supermarket substitutions reported by online shoppers in a new poll. Just over a third of online grocery shoppers (34%) reported having received a substitution in their most recent grocery delivery, the survey for consumer group Which? found. Asda was the worst offender". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Mushrooms swapped for tampons among bizarre UK supermarket substitutions Mushrooms in place of tampons, a frozen pizza substituted for tinned peaches, and cream crackers instead of Christmas crackers. These are among the “bizarre” supermarket substitutions reported by online shoppers in a new poll. Just over a third of online grocery shoppers (34%) reported having received a substitution in their most recent grocery delivery, the survey for consumer group Which? found. Asda was the worst offender
